Comment:
Honeybrook: I thought it would be interesting and helpful to post a game by the great Alexander Alekhine, many times world chess champion and in my mind probably the greatest player of all time.  But who can say?

Many notes are Alekhine's and can be found in his book of his best games. Where my notes are added I will specify as 'Honeybrook' or 'H'.

Honeybrook:  The beginning of the Ruy Lopez. An opening, according to www.chessgames.com's database, white wins 35%, black 22% and draws 42%. It's greatest popularity was enjoyed during the first two decades of the 20th century.  But it is by no means forgotten, Bobby Fischer often employed the opening with great success... but then he was Bobby Fischer.

H: The usual challenge...
H:  ...and the most common response:  retreat.  Though certainly taking down the knight (exchange variation) is a viable option.
H: We now see the Ruy Lopez-Russian Defense (C79).
H: We now see the Ruy Lopez-Russian Defense (C79).

Alekhine begins:
This permits white to start an immediate action in the center without being obliged to protect first the King pawn by Re1 or Qe2 which would have been the case after 5...Be7.

Honeybrook: this to me is a sophisticated note that requires some thought to appreciate. For in truth the King pawn is now unprotected and easy prey for black's knight. But anticipating the freeing of the bishop on c1 to attack black's queen from g5, the black knight is reluctant to abandon its post just to capture the king pawn.  The knight would stand on an unprotected square and have to retreat in the face of Re1 or d3 thus giving up a tempo.
H: Laying groundwork for a solid white center while black's will be dismantled.
H: Unpins the knight and moves the bishop to a much more active square.
H: White's space grows, yet if black responds with exd white is ready to seize the e-file with Re1.
H: Knight on f6 freed from potential pin while room made for castle.

A: This blockade maneuver was introduced by Bogoljubow against me in Rotterdam 1929. Its peculiarity leads generally to slow positional battles of heavy calibre.

H: Where can the knight go? There are no excellent homes for it to land, retreat is forced.  Meanwhile white's position has room to move while black's suffocatingly cramped.  Plus, the d5 knight controls e6.
H: Total retreat but designed ultimately to get the knight onto d7.
H: A trade of bishops would benefit black by trading a cramped black bishop for a mobile white one and do much to relieve black's cramped position.  So white's bishop takes up a post aimed at h7.

A: Keres tried against me, in 1935, a more aggressive line of play involving the renunciation of 0-0 in favor of 9...h6 10. c4 Qc8 11. Ne1 g5 12. Nc3 Nh5.

H: Penetrating white's space and pins the knight against the queen.
H: White advances, stakes out more of the queenside and leaves c3 open for the knight.
H: Opens the king's defensive wall asserting control over h5 and f5.
H: Opens the king's defensive wall asserting control over h5 and f5.
H: Opens the king's defensive wall asserting control over h5 and f5.
H: Opens the king's defensive wall asserting control over h5 and f5.
H: Opens the king's defensive wall asserting control over h5 and f5.
H: Opens the king's defensive wall asserting control over h5 and f5.
H: The bishop is running out of places to dwell.

A: Preparing for Nh4 which if played instead of Qe2 would be met by 14...Bxe4.

H: White's formidable structure has weaknesses, namely the pawns on c4 and e4.
H: Five of black's pieces are on contiguous squares.
H: The rooks can see each other.
